document.docAuthor: Hedges, Blair, Couloux, Arnaud & Vidal, Nicolas
document.masterDocTitle: Molecular phylogeny, classification, and biogeography of West Indian racer snakes of the Tribe Alsophiini (Squamata, Dipsadidae, Xenodontinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Molecular phylogeny, classification, and biogeography of West Indian racer snakes of the Tribe Alsophiini (Squamata, Dipsadidae, Xenodontinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type species.
Uromacer oxyrhynchus
Duméril and Bibron, 1853
: 722
.
Diagnosis. See diagnosis for the subtribe Uromacerina .

Remarks.
Uromacer
(
Fig. 3
H) is known only from Hispaniola and includes three species (
Table 1
;
Fig. 2
). All are arboreal, and they are the only West Indian alsophiines occupying an arboreal niche. As is typical of arboreal species, they are slender-bodied, and two of the species (
U. frenatus
and
U. oxyrhynchus
) are more slender than
U. catesbyi
and feed exclusively on lizards;
U. catesbyi
feeds on lizards and frogs (
Henderson 1984
;
Henderson et al. 1987
). As expected,
U. frenatus
and
U. oxyrhynchus
are closest relatives (
Figs. 1
and
4
); we place them here in the
oxyrhynchus
Group and place
U. catesbyi
in the
catesbyi
Group. All three species have green on their bodies, as concealing coloration, consistent with many arboreal species of snakes. There is considerable geographic variation in morphology within at least two of the species (
U. catesbyi
and
U. frenatus
) which has led to the recognition of 12 subspecies (
Table 1
) (
Cochran 1941
;
Horn 1969
; Schwartz 1970 , 1976), some of which may prove to be distinct species.

caption.paragraph: TABLE 3. Divergence times (Ma) and their confidence/credibility intervals (CI) among Alsophiini (Serpentes, Dipsadidae , Xenodontinae ). Tree nodes refer to those numbered in Fig. 4.

subSubSection.paragraph: To examine the influence of the various priors, analyses were done without selected calibrations and altering the rttm prior. After removing the molecular-based, secondary calibration point, leaving only the three geologic calibrations, the divergence time estimates dropped by an average of 8.4 %. Removing the 37.2 Ma maximum geologic calibration resulted in an average change of only 0.8 % in time estimates. Lowering the ingroup-root (rttm) prior by 12 % to 20 Ma lowered divergence times an average of only 2.1 % whereas increasing the rttm prior by about the same amount to 25 Ma resulted in an average increase in time estimates of only 0.6 %. These results indicate that, as expected, the calibration priors have a larger influence on the posterior time estimates than the rttm prior, but that the differences in either case are relatively minor, especially considering the large credibility intervals.
